name: Joshua Michael Steever
bio:
Joshua, founder of the Aryan Strikeforce, is serving a 20-year sentence after becoming the main target of an FBI operation that manufactured a drugs for guns conspiracy from start to finish.

PennLive reports that federal agents orchestrated all aspects of the alleged "drugs-for-guns" plot, using fake methamphetamine and staging sales for gift cards allegedly meant to buy weapons.

Steever ultimately pleaded guilty to conspiracy to distribute controlled substances despite no real meth being involved.

As National Justice notes, there was no existing conspiracy until FBI undercover employees infiltrated the group, supplied the drugs, posed as buyers, and drove the entire plan. Several defendants, including a cancer-stricken, homeless co-defendant, Jacob Mark Robards, were drawn into the operation while facing desperate circumstances.

name: Stephen Pattison
bio:
Stephen is currently serving a 9-year federal prison sentence after being convicted of possession of a firearm and ammunition by a convicted felon.

He is scheduled for release on August 23, 2028.

During an Upstate New York traffic stop, police realized that Stephen had a warrant out for his arrest for absconding parole in Missouri and made an arrest. During the arrest, police saw that Stephen had decorated his cell phone with a ‘1488’ sticker, which seemed to give police the moral authority to place Stephen under maximum state pressure.

Shortly thereafter, a search warrant was issued for Stephen’s residence where illicit firearms and ammunition were discovered by an incredible assembly of both federal and local law enforcement. Unfortunately for Stephen, this selective use of state power against pro-White suspects was only the beginning.

After a misguided attempt to conceal Stephen’s ownership of the weapons resulted in the indictment of his friend and the mother of his children, Stephen admitted to his error in judgment and accepted a plea bargain on a weapons possession charge.

The maximum penalty would net up to ten years in prison; however, sentencing guidelines suggested a maximum of 4.75 years for a person with Stephen’s record. A key, yet often overlooked clause within many plea agreements would prevent Stephen from withdrawing his plea, even if the judge had decided to increase the suggested punishment.

Around two months later, the same government that just signed a plea agreement with Stephen recommended to Judge Larimer that he be sentenced to 10 years in prison, with a great emphasis placed on his National Socialist views. Larimer seemingly took heed, issuing to Stephen an 8 year long prison sentence.

During Stephen’s sentencing phase, his own attorney referred to his views as "repugnant to most Americans," and called him a "neo-Nazi." The unoriginal Larimer would suggest to Stephen that he use his 96 months in prison to get an education and to read the antiracist Black poet, Maya Angelou.

Since he was 15, Stephen had been associated with pro-White societal outcasts, a lifestyle that few know anything about. Stephen had previously told the court that the original purpose for his affiliations was for self-defense in an ever diversifying and increasingly dangerous America. While Stephen’s life was certainly not perfect, for the unapologetic White man, the alternative was unthinkable and undoable. It became not only difficult, but even undesirable to rejoin a society that is inherently anti-White. Eventually, a few mistakes would lead Stephen to join prison gangs, again as a means of survival in multicultural American facilities.

When Stephen was out of prison, this wasn’t a direct problem; however, once sentenced to 8 years, survival again became an issue. When a fellow White inmate was discovered to be selling weapons to members of another race, Stephen was given a choice by his ‘crew’: ‘correct’ a traitor, or spend 8 years in prison with no allies.

Stephen chose the former and attacked the weapons dealer, informing prison staff that Whites were going to make a move, and it was merely his time to put in ‘work.’

Perhaps because of this, Larimer would rescind his previous sentence and handed out an extra year to Stephen, making 9 in total.

Stephen’s attorney had presciently warned Larimer that singling out Stephen for a long sentence in the American prison system would do nothing to help his rehabilitation — but it seems that when a White convict is involved, systemic responsibility is conveniently shifted onto the individual.
